page.title: 09Levin Down Nature Reserve
page.content: The south facing slope of Levin Down was established as a nature reserve in 1981. The reserve in managed by the Sussex Trust for Nature Conservation, by agreement with the landowner , the Goodwood Estate Co. Covering twenty acres, the reserve is a fine example of chalk downland which has not been cultivated for many centuries; a type of land not very common these days. Rich in plant life, surveys have revealed more than 180 different species. The reserve is also an important habitat for butterflies and birds. The site also supports a large colony of juniper, a shrub fast disappearing in the south of England. Many varieties of the orchid family grow here including early purple, common spotted, fragrant, bee, frog & autumn ladies tresses. Autumn gentian & rampion also grow here in profusion.
